<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 117, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 232]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 353, 910, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 806, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

athletePQRST
finishing time/s22.5024.4025.2026.5023.20
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 180, 348, 199]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 134, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 777, 227]]<|/det|> Athlete P won the race and was 0.70 s ahead of the athlete in second place. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 235, 133, 254]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 234, 777, 253]]<|/det|> Athlete P won the race and was 1.90 s ahead of the athlete in second place. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 261, 133, 280]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 260, 777, 279]]<|/det|> Athlete S won the race and was 1.30 s ahead of the athlete in second place. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 287, 133, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 286, 777, 305]]<|/det|> Athlete S won the race and was 2.10 s ahead of the athlete in second place. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 331, 97, 350]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 331, 636, 350]]<|/det|> A student investigates the motion of a ball rolling down a slope. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 625, 380]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the speed \(\nu\) of the ball at different times \(t\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 388, 818, 551]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 564, 531, 583]]<|/det|> Which statement describes the motion of the ball? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 593, 134, 611]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 593, 421, 611]]<|/det|> The acceleration is not constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 619, 134, 637]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 618, 390, 637]]<|/det|> The acceleration is negative. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 645, 134, 664]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 358, 663]]<|/det|> The speed is decreasing. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 134, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 353, 689]]<|/det|> The velocity is constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 714, 96, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 714, 504, 733]]<|/det|> Which statement about acceleration is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 743, 134, 761]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 743, 539, 761]]<|/det|> It is related to the changing speed of an object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 769, 134, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 769, 556, 787]]<|/det|> It is the distance an object travels in one second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 795, 133, 814]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 795, 816, 814]]<|/det|> It is the force acting on an object divided by the distance it travels in one second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 821, 134, 839]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 821, 653, 839]]<|/det|> It is the force acting on an object when it is near to the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 779, 88]]<|/det|> Which statement correctly describes the effects of placing a heavy load in a car? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 100, 695, 117]]<|/det|> It is easier to accelerate the car and easier to bring the car to rest. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 125, 745, 144]]<|/det|> It is easier to accelerate the car but more difficult to bring the car to rest. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 131, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 152, 803, 170]]<|/det|> It is more difficult to accelerate the car and more difficult to bring the car to rest. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 178, 745, 196]]<|/det|> It is more difficult to accelerate the car but easier to bring the car to rest. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 96, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 500, 241]]<|/det|> A space probe is taken from the Earth to Mars. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 253, 920, 286]]<|/det|> The force of gravity on the surface of Mars is less than the force of gravity on the surface of the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 299, 920, 332]]<|/det|> How do the weight and the mass of a space probe on the surface of Mars compare to their values when the probe is on the surface of the Earth? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 343, 515, 470]]<|/det|>
weight on Marsmass on Mars
Adecreaseddecreased
Bdecreasedunchanged
Cunchangeddecreased
Dunchangedunchanged

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 752, 133, 769]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 752, 500, 769]]<|/det|> The resultant force on the satellite is zero. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 778, 133, 796]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 778, 608, 796]]<|/det|> The resultant force on the satellite is towards the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 804, 131, 822]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 804, 628, 822]]<|/det|> The resultant force on the satellite is away from the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 831, 133, 848]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 831, 665, 848]]<|/det|> The resultant force on the satellite is in the direction of motion.

The pressure due to the liquid at this depth is \(9000 \text{Pa}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 495, 386, 514]]<|/det|> What is the density of the liquid? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 133, 542]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 776, 542]]<|/det|> 15 kg/ m³ B 540 kg/ m³ C 1500 kg/ m³ D 54 000 kg/ m³ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 568, 107, 587]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 568, 920, 602]]<|/det|> Which row describes the forces between the molecules and the motion of the molecules in a solid? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 500, 758]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A room is heated by a radiator. The diagrams X and Y show two possible circulations of hot air, which heat the room. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 112, 917, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 273, 730, 293]]<|/det|> Which diagram and reason explain the heating of the room by convection? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 645, 432]]<|/det|>
diagramreason
AXair density decreases when air is heated
BXair density increases when air is heated
CYair density decreases when air is heated
DYair density increases when air is heated
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 458, 104, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 458, 579, 477]]<|/det|> Two copper containers P and Q are filled with hot water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 489, 517, 508]]<|/det|> The diagrams are both drawn to the same scale. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[267, 515, 730, 623]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 636, 747, 655]]<|/det|> Container P emits more infrared radiation from its surfaces than container Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 667, 403, 685]]<|/det|> What is a possible reason for this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 695, 134, 714]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 695, 779, 714]]<|/det|> The surfaces of P are painted white and the surfaces of Q are painted black. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 722, 133, 740]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 722, 635, 740]]<|/det|> The surfaces of P are shiny and the surfaces of Q are dull. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 749, 133, 767]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 749, 660, 767]]<|/det|> The surfaces of P have a smaller area than the surfaces of Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 775, 133, 794]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 775, 512, 792]]<|/det|> The water in P is hotter than the water in Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 428, 107, 446]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 348, 446]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 456, 134, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 456, 920, 490]]<|/det|> The speed of light in glass is equal to the speed of light in a vacuum multiplied by the refractive index of glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 496, 134, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 496, 920, 530]]<|/det|> The incident angle of a light ray at an air-glass surface is the angle between the ray and the glass surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 540, 134, 560]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 540, 876, 571]]<|/det|> The sine of the critical angle at an air-glass surface is equal to \(\frac{1}{\text{refractive index of glass}}.\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 134, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 575, 920, 609]]<|/det|> The angle of refraction for light passing through an air-glass surface is proportional to the angle of incidence at that surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 636, 107, 654]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 636, 774, 654]]<|/det|> An intruder alarm sensor detects that a person is warmer than his surroundings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 666, 620, 683]]<|/det|> Which type of electromagnetic wave does the sensor detect? An echo returns 0.010 s later from a fish which is 7.5 m from the dolphin. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 863, 504, 880]]<|/det|> What is the speed of the sound wave in water? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 891, 133, 908]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 891, 740, 908]]<|/det|> 0.075 m/s B 0.15 m/s C 750 m/s D 1500 m/s

Each nail is tested individually. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 569, 375]]<|/det|> Which nail becomes the strongest permanent magnet? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 387, 549, 540]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student wants to demagnetise a steel bar. He uses the apparatus shown. He switches on the circuit for a few seconds and then switches off. He finds that the steel bar is still magnetised.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 114, 585, 304]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 317, 472, 336]]<|/det|>
What should he do to improve his method?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 346, 134, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 345, 616, 365]]<|/det|>
change the supply from an alternating to a direct voltage

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 373, 133, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 373, 406, 392]]<|/det|>
use a lower alternating voltage

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 400, 133, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 400, 688, 418]]<|/det|>
remove the steel bar from the coil whilst the circuit is switched on

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 426, 133, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 426, 443, 444]]<|/det|>
use a coil that has fewer turns on it

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 470, 106, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 504, 489]]<|/det|>
A cloth is used to rub an uncharged plastic rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 500, 480, 518]]<|/det|>
Both the rod and the cloth become charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 902, 549]]<|/det|>
Why does the plastic rod become negatively charged and the cloth become positively charged?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 133, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 559, 653, 578]]<|/det|>
The rod gains electrons and the cloth gains positive charges.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 586, 133, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 586, 593, 604]]<|/det|>
The rod gains electrons and the cloth loses electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 133, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 612, 593, 631]]<|/det|>
The rod loses electrons and the cloth gains electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 133, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 640, 650, 657]]<|/det|>
The rod loses electrons and the cloth loses positive charges.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 823, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 680, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the magnetic field due to a current in a solenoid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 467, 120]]<|/det|>
Where is the magnetic field the strongest?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[227, 128, 769, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 402, 106, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 402, 693, 421]]<|/det|>
A beam of electrons is passed through the magnetic field of a magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 433, 774, 452]]<|/det|>
How must the magnet be positioned to deflect the beam in the direction shown?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 460, 845, 897]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 581, 89]]<|/det|>
Uranium-235 can undergo nuclear fission in many ways.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 744, 120]]<|/det|>
Which equation correctly shows a possible fission reaction for uranium-235?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 135, 138, 160]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 134, 560, 163]]<|/det|>
\(^{1}_{0}\mathrm{n} + ^{235}_{92}\mathrm{U} \rightarrow ^{141}_{56}\mathrm{Ba} + ^{92}_{36}\mathrm{Kr} + ^{3}_{0}^{1}\mathrm{n}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 183, 138, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 183, 560, 211]]<|/det|>
\(^{1}_{0}\mathrm{n} + ^{235}_{92}\mathrm{U} \rightarrow ^{91}_{38}\mathrm{Sr} + ^{144}_{54}\mathrm{Xe} + ^{2}_{1}^{1}\mathrm{n}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 234, 138, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>c</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 234, 581, 262]]<|/det|>
\(^{1}_{0}\mathrm{n} + ^{235}_{92}\mathrm{U} \rightarrow ^{95}_{37}\mathrm{Rb} + ^{136}_{55}\mathrm{Cs} + ^{3}_{0}^{1}\mathrm{n}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 282, 138, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 282, 560, 310]]<|/det|>
\(^{1}_{0}\mathrm{n} + ^{235}_{92}\mathrm{U} \rightarrow ^{87}_{35}\mathrm{Br} + ^{146}_{57}\mathrm{La} + ^{4}_{0}^{1}\mathrm{n}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 341, 106, 359]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 341, 510, 359]]<|/det|>
A radioactive material has a half-life of 20 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 373, 541, 392]]<|/det|>
A sample of the material contains \(8.0 \times 10^{10}\) atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 403, 564, 422]]<|/det|>
How many atomic nuclei have decayed after 60 days?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 432, 133, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 432, 238, 451]]<|/det|>
\(1.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 432, 300, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 432, 400, 451]]<|/det|>
\(4.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 432, 466, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 432, 571, 451]]<|/det|>
\(6.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 432, 636, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 432, 739, 451]]<|/det|>
\(7.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 476, 106, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 922, 510]]<|/det|>
A thin sheet of paper is placed between a radioactive source and a radiation detector. The count rate falls to a very low reading.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 520, 682, 640]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 631, 674]]<|/det|>
From this result, which type of radiation is the source emitting?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 685, 134, 703]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 685, 243, 703]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 712, 134, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 712, 241, 730]]<|/det|>
\(\beta\) -particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 134, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 740, 205, 758]]<|/det|>
\(\gamma\) -rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 766, 136, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 766, 210, 784]]<|/det|>
X-rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 813, 91]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays are emitted by radioactive nuclei when they decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 564, 120]]<|/det|>
Which emissions can be deflected by an electric field?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 134, 150]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 133, 408, 150]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles and \(\beta\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 177]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 160, 371, 177]]<|/det|>
\(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 187, 134, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 187, 371, 204]]<|/det|>
\(\gamma\) -rays and \(\alpha\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 214, 134, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 214, 428, 231]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays
